newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo naphtha firmer, LSWR seen under pressure.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo naphtha firmer, LSWR seen under pressure.

text.p: Tokyo naphtha prices were firmer on Thursday, buoyed by gains in crude prices on the ACCESS after-hours system, traders said.
Open-spec naphtha second-half March was assessed at $231.00/233.00 and first-half April at $230.50/232.00, compared to $228.50/230.50 and $227.00/229.00 respectively on Wednesday.
Spreads narrowed with the one-month spread from second-half March assessed at $1.50/3.00, against $3.00/4.00 on Wednesday.
On Wednesday, second-half March switched hands at $231.00, first-half April at $230.00 and second-half March/second-half April at $3.00, traders said.
Prompt naphtha supplies remain more than sufficient, traders said, adding that output cuts at Singapore refineries had yet to have an impact on the market.
In the low sulphur waxy residue market, February cargo prices are expected to be weighed down by slumping fuel oil prices, traders said.
They said buyers had kept to the sidelines, waiting for prices to come down and for the results of Korea Electric Power Corp's March delivery LSWR buying tender.
Gas oil traders said they were still wary about market direction, after recent sharp losses.
